item.title: Splatoon 3 Update 11.0.0 Brings Some Major Gameplay Changes
item.content:encoded:
Splatoon 3 is getting a major update later this week, and if you thought Update 11.0.0 would just be bringing insubstantial quality-of-life improvements, think again, because some pretty major gameplay changes are coming.

In a news post on the official Nintendo website, the company reveals that Splatoon 3 Update 11.0.0, which is set to arrive on January 29th (that's this Thursday at time of writing), will introduce "new mechanics and other changes to freshen things up in the Splatlands".

First up, the update will add a new system called Flow Aura, which is essentially a killstreak system. Racking up splats in quick succession will put you in the Flow Aura state, which will increase your speed and defense, and you can keep this state going by scoring more splats or assists.

To help you work out how close you might be to a KO in Splatoon 3, the new update will also make enemy health bars visible, although the bar will only show when an enemy has just been hit. You won't be able to see it if they're in cover or if they've jumped into their ink (short of certain specials).

Splatoon 3's hitboxes are also being adjusted to compensate for players' increased expertise with motion controls; landing a shot on an opponent in swim form will be harder, but attacks are easier to land on enemies in kid form with certain weapons.

If you'd like to see exactly what's changing, you can check out the full patch notes for Splatoon 3 Update 11.0.0 right here. The list has some fairly straightforward quality-of-life tweaks alongside the flashier stuff.

This latest Splatoon 3 update comes despite Nintendo's assurance that the game would receive no further content drops back in September 2024, although it's true that this update doesn't feature any new weapons or gear.

The studio continuing to pay attention to Splatoon 3 also arguably stokes the rumor fire for a Switch 2 Edition, as distinct from the more incremental update the game received back in June.

You can check out Splatoon 3 right now on Nintendo Switch. Be sure to read our review from way back in 2022 to see what we thought of it then.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Nintendo Reveals Virtual Boy Switch Online Launch Lineup, More Games Coming
item.content:encoded:
If you've been waiting on tenterhooks to discover which Virtual Boy games will be making their way to the Switch Online service next month, wait no more, for Nintendo has announced the Virtual Boy launch lineup for Switch Online.

In a new trailer, Nintendo shows off the seven games that will be available to check out when the Virtual Boy lands on the gaming giant's subscription service on February 17th, and one game is of particular interest (to me, at least).

Alongside obvious choices like Teleroboxer and Virtual Boy: Wario Land slides The Mansion of Innsmouth, a previously Japan-exclusive first-person horror game with (believe it or not) very heavy Lovecraft vibes. It's a curio, but hey, if you're checking the Virtual Boy out already, you may as well give it a shot.

Here's a full list of all of the games that will be available for the Virtual Boy via Nintendo Switch Online on February 17th. As a reminder, you're going to need the dedicated Virtual Boy accessory to play these.

  • Teleroboxer
  • Galactic Pinball
  • Red Alarm
  • Golf
  • Virtual Boy: Wario Land
  • 3D Tetris
  • The Mansion of Innsmouth

All of these games will support the Switch Online's quality-of-life features, including rewinding, save states, and control customization.

That's not all, though. Here's a list of games that will be coming to the Switch Online's Virtual Boy library throughout the rest of 2026.

  • Mario Clash
  • Mario's Tennis
  • Jack Bros.
  • Space Invaders Virtual Collection
  • Virtual Bowling
  • Vertical Force
  • V-Tetris

They'll be joined by two previously unreleased games for the Virtual Boy, namely Zero Racers and D-Hopper, both of which will be available sometime later this year. Who knows? Maybe they'll spark a Virtual Boy tournament revival.

If you're not a fan of the Virtual Boy's garish red filter, then there will be an option to change the filter's color, although if you're playing with the Cardboard Model version of the Virtual Boy peripheral, that feature will sadly be absent.

Nintendo's slate of Virtual Boy games will land on Switch Online on February 17th, and you'll need an Expansion Pack membership and one of the two Virtual Boy peripheral models to check them out. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Helldivers 2 Siege Breakers Warbond Brings Patriotic Destruction Next Week
item.content:encoded:
Sony and developer Arrowhead have announced Siege Breakers, the latest Warbond for Helldivers 2, and this one's all about big, loud explosions, which are, as I'm sure we can all agree, the ideal way to spread democracy throughout the galaxy.

In many ways, Siege Breakers provides the perfect counterpoint to Redacted Regiment, the Warbond from a couple of weeks ago, because that one focused on stealth and this one...absolutely does not.

The first major addition to Helldivers 2 in Siege Breakers is the LAS-16 Trident, an updated version of the beloved weapon from the original arsenal. This one fires six beams instead of three, and when it comes to annihilating enemies, that's definitely a marked improvement.

If you prefer to get up close and personal (well, even more up close and personal), then the new CQC-20 Breaching Hammer stratagem will allow you to do just that. It's a massive sledgehammer that can optionally also explode. I say "optionally", but that sounds pretty mandatory to me.

Joining the new hammer is the GL-28 Belt-Fed Grenade Launcher, which, as the name suggests, is an explosive weapon that lets you continuously fire grenades. It should be perfect for those pesky Terminid hives.

Should you prefer to make one very loud noise rather than a series of slightly less loud noises, you may want to check out the EAT-411 Leveller, a single-shot missile launcher with a serious kick.

Lastly, if all of this ordnance isn't working for you and you need to protect yourself, the G/SH-39 Shield should help you do just that by providing a barrier that should stop more than a few Automaton shots.

All of this is, of course, coming in addition to new armors, capes, and other accouterments to help your Helldiver stand out and look snazzy on the battlefield.

Helldivers 2's Siege Breakers Warbond launches across all platforms on February 3rd. The game is available now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S, and you can read our review here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Ubisoft Cuts Continue as Voluntary Redundancies Hit Paris Head Office
item.content:encoded:
Ubisoft is enacting another voluntary redundancy program, but rather than one of the publisher's many studio locations, it's the Paris head office where roles are at risk this time around.

As spotted by Gamesindustry.biz, Ubisoft looks to be cutting around 200 staff roles from its Paris location, which constitutes around 18% of the studio's overall staff. That's not an insubstantial cut at all.

At the moment, the redundancy program is strictly voluntary, but Ubisoft has previous form with following up a voluntary redundancy initiative by laying off staff who didn't take said redundancy, so there's every chance that'll happen again if not enough Paris staff are enticed.

News of Ubisoft's latest voluntary redundancy program comes after the company announced a major restructuring effort last week, with the long-awaited Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time remake being shut down as part of that effort.

The game was canned along with several other projects in Ubisoft's pipeline, all as part of an attempt to streamline the studio's output and focus on profitability.

Ubisoft's decision was met with outrage by French union Solidaires Informatique, along with a call for Ubisoft employees to strike. 

That call was repeated today after the voluntary redundancy program's announcement, and it seems Ubisoft employees have indeed voted in favor of action, with the strike due to take place between February 10th and 12th.

In general, it's not been the best of times for Ubisoft recently, with impending lawsuits from former execs, studio shutdowns, and disappointing financial results all lining up outside the publisher's door.

If Ubisoft continues at this pace, I can't imagine the remaining employees will be particularly happy or comfortable, which could cause further problems for the company down the line. Stay tuned for more on this and all other things Ubisoft.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Capcom's Q3 Profits Jump as Monster Hunter Wilds Sales Reach 11m
item.content:encoded:
Capcom has released its Q3 financial results for this fiscal year, and when it comes to consolidated results for the nine-month period as a whole, the studio is doing pretty well, as are some of its core franchises.

In its latest financial presentation, Capcom reveals that its sales, operating profit, and ordinary profit are all up by varying degrees when compared to March-December 2024, and the studio is on track for a better 2025-26 fiscal year as a whole, too.

When it comes to specific games, Capcom says the Resident Evil series, along with Street Fighter 6, "continued to grow" in sales terms, and that Monster Hunter Wilds managed to surpass the 11 million sales mark within the March-December period as well.

The new sales figure means Monster Hunter Wilds has garnered another million sales since the end of March, which rather validates Capcom's concern that sales slowed down dramatically after launch, although whether the so-called "PS5 barrier" is to blame is another matter.

Capcom also says that sales of the Resident Evil 4 remake and Resident Evil Village grew thanks to the announcement of Resident Evil Requiem, which is due to arrive next month. Both games had crossed the ten million sales barrier at last count.

With regards to Capcom's future, the company has a pretty packed slate. The aforementioned Resident Evil Requiem leads the pack, but there's also Monster Hunter Stories 3 and Mega Man Star Force Legacy Collection to look forward to in March.

In total, Capcom sold 34.64 million game units between March and December 2025, which is around four million units higher than the previous year's total. It's fair to say Capcom is on the up right now.

We'll have to wait and see what else Capcom has in store for the year, but for now, the company will no doubt be celebrating this past nine-month period's improvements. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
